title: 107_hr1633
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Burt Lake Band of Ottawa and Chippewa Indians Act". The Burt Lake Band of Ottawa and Chippewa Indians, along with other tribes, are descendants of signatories to historical treaties. The Burt Lake Band consists of over 600 members residing close to their ancestral homeland in Cheboygan County. The Burt Lake Band of Ottawa and Chippewa Indians, along with other Michigan Odawa/Ottawa groups, formed the Northern Michigan Ottawa Association in 1948. The Band maintained its political and social existence with a tribal government and pursued a successful land claim with the Indian Claims Commission. In 1975, the Northern Michigan Ottawa Association petitioned under the Indian Reorganization Act. The Burt Lake Band of Ottawa and Chippewa Indians, part of the Northern Michigan Ottawa Association, petitioned under the Indian Reorganization Act to form a government, but the Bureau of Indian Affairs failed to act. The Band has had continuous dealings with the United States Government, the government of Michigan, and local governments since 1836. The Burt Lake Band of Ottawa and Chippewa Indians, also known as the Band, consists of members enrolled under the Secretary of the Interior. Federal recognition is sought under this Act. Federal recognition of the Burt Lake Band of Ottawa and Chippewa Indians is reaffirmed, granting them eligibility for federal services and benefits provided to recognized Indians. This includes provisions under the Indian Reorganization Act, with any conflicting laws not applicable to the Band and its members. The Act reaffirms federal recognition of the Burt Lake Band of Ottawa and Chippewa Indians, granting them eligibility for federal services within a 70-mile radius of their reservation boundaries. Services can also be provided outside this area unless prohibited by law. SEC. 5. REAFFIRMATION OF RIGHTS.

All rights and privileges of the Band and its members are reaffirmed, regardless of any previous abrogation or diminishment. Existing rights of the Tribe are preserved, and any legal claims to enforce denied rights are unaffected by this Act.

SEC. 6. TRIBAL LANDS. SEC. 6. TRIBAL LANDS.

The Band's tribal lands include all real property held by the Band, acquired by the Secretary in trust for the Band. The acquired property becomes part of the Band's reservation.

SEC. 7. MEMBERSHIP.

Within 18 months of this Act, the Band must submit a membership roll to the Secretary, based on qualifications in the Band's governing document. The Secretary will publish notice in the Federal Register, and the Band must maintain and update the roll. SEC. 8. CONSTITUTION AND GOVERNING BODY. The Secretary must conduct secret ballot elections for adopting a new constitution for the Band within 24 months of the enactment of the Act. Until then, the current governing documents will serve as interim governing documents. After adopting the constitution, elections for officials must be held within 6 months. The Band shall conduct secret ballot elections to elect officials as per the governing constitution. Interim governing bodies will remain until new officials are elected.
